Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Monolithic Aerogel Designs for Daylighting Applications
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is in the use of aerogels in daylighting applications to efficiently incorporate natural lighting in building design, benefitting society by significantly decreasing energy consumption and simultaneously improving environments. Natural light is linked to health and productivity The daylighting market ascribes high value to natural light transmission, optical clarity, and thermal insulation; however, existing products generally fail to achieve all three. The proposed technology decouples thermal performance from window clarity, allowing end users to experience the benefits of increased natural light without being resigned to low translucency or high heat or cooling loss. This solution will provide the benefits of natural lighting while improving overall energy efficiency in buildings. As a direct result, architects and glazing contractors will not be limited by thermal considerations when adding windows to structures. Further, it addresses a need for windows that are acoustically insulating.<br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this STTR Phase I project lies in the combination of a proprietary design with a licensed aerogel fabrication method to yield a transformative, elegant window product that promotes natural lighting and reduces energy waste. Silica aerogel monoliths have outstanding insulating ability and superior optical properties to materials currently used in daylighting products; however, traditional methods for making monolithic aerogels are time- and labor-intensive. The patented fabrication method employed in this project is advantageous for several reasons, including ease of automation, speed of processing and production of consistent monolithic aerogels, and offers an alternative to existing daylighting solutions with the potential to transform a generally stagnant industry. To mitigate the risks associated with bringing an aerogel window product to market, this project focuses on: (1) improving aerogel molding technology; (2) developing a proprietary innovation to build larger systems; (3) experimenting with dye-doped and etched aerogels for tailored aesthetic effects; (4) fabricating aerogels for two prototype windows (one colorless, one aesthetically enhanced); (5) developing a simplified window assembly method to fabricate two prototype windows; and (6) studying the aerogel precursor supply chain and use of alternative chemistries.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
THE PROJECT OUTCOMES OF SUNTHRU'S PHASE I NSF STTR AWARD.

 

Through our Phase I award we reached five major milestones that have brought SunThru closer to commercializing aerogel inserts for window products::

 

1.     We have built strong relationships with members within our industry including our customers. Through the NSF I-Corps program we learned the importance of customer discovery and conducted over a hundred interviews. Through these interviews we built lasting relationships that have been used to direct our research and development activities. We have also been able to build a compelling commercialization plan that is based on the facts that we gained from our industry partners. These relationships will be extremely valuable now that we are beginning to scale our manufacturing capabilities and will look to integrate our product into actual Insulated Glazing Unit (IGU).

 

2.     We were able to develop a process for manufacturing highly transparent aerogels. Throughout history aerogels have been seen as a promising technology for enhancing the insulating factor of window products. However, until recent years aerogels have been far too opaque to be accepted by consumers as they would obstruct views out of the windows. Now due to our phase I award we will be able to join the limited number of aerogel manufacturers who can make transparent aerogels and acceptable for use in high volume window products. Also, these transparent aerogels were featured in industry publications that brought significant attention to our product and helped us connect with even more customers.

 

3.     We completed the construction of five aerogel IGUs that utilized our transparent aerogels. These units demonstrated that using existing materials and manufacturing procedures we could repeatedly integrate our product into existing double pane products. Silica aerogel can be a fragile material and without proper handling methods can lead to high scrap rates that we now can look to avoid. These completed aerogel IGUs allowed us to travel to our industry partners and demonstrate the advancements we have made in aerogel transparency. During these trips we were able to discuss in great detail the needs and capabilities of our customers. These conversations helped us develop a product roadmap that could be used to directly meet our customer?s needs. With our prototypes we were able to learn that our customers wanted us to next demonstrate that we can make larger aerogels and also develop a manufacturing process that could be scaled cost effectively.

 

4.     We proved that layered molding will work to produce multiple aerogels in a single batch. As we scale to large sized monoliths it is just as crucial to scale to larger amounts of aerogels being produced per batch. Layering is really a multiplier to our productivity and will allow us to meet the demanding needs of our customers.

 

5.     We completed the design of the Supercritical Oven for Monolithic Aerogels (SOMA). This device is the key to bringing our technology out of the lab. Our customers have made it clear that as of today what stands in the way of commercializing an aerogel insert for window products is the need for a scalable manufacturing method for producing millions of square feet of large aerogel each year. We have designed SOMA to allow us to scale to much larger aerogel sizes. In combination with our advancements in layered molding techniques we will be able to produce significant volumes of these aerogels per year with a single device.

 

 

For aerogels to be a commercial success as a window product our customers need a manufacturer to prove that they have developed a scalable process that is cost effective and consistent. Due to our achievements in Phase I, we are positioned to do just this in an NSF Phase II award.  SunThru's next set of technical goals will be to build out a pilot manufacturing space and line around our SOMA technology. We will also work with key industry partners to integrate our product into IGUs, so these products can undergo industry standard testing and be qualified for long term use. Due to the support given by NSF we have been able to learn how to properly operate our company. We believe that we are capable of carrying out a successful Phase II award that can culminate in the sale of our product and continuation of scaling our manufacturing capabilities.
